awd_titl_txt: SRS-RN: Land Use in Regional Sustainability Transitions: Establishing a Network of Research and Practice to Support Governance in Linked Urban and Rural Systems of Massachusetts
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to promote sustainability and resilience in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts through integrated land use planning and management. Using land for one purpose, such as energy generation, can have implications for other purposes, such as sustainable food systems and forest ecosystems. Regional landscapes reflect complex political, economic, social, and cultural forces. Over time, choices made by local, state, regional, and national actors create mosaics of land use with a range of costs and benefits. Future land use choices will affect strategies that are essential to achieve regional sustainability and climate resilience, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions; ensuring food security; supporting healthy economies and communities; and maintaining and enhancing natural environments. However, collaboration and coordination of land use planning and management across actors, regions, and scales is challenging. This project will advance sustainability and climate resilience goals in Massachusetts, support undergraduate and graduate education, and serve as a model for integrated land use governance in other regions with connected urban and rural communities.
 
This project will explore the challenges and opportunities of integrated governance by investigating how land use choices mediate trade-offs, synergies, risks, benefits, and equity among sectors, scales, and communities. To achieve this goal, Tuler and colleagues will expand existing partnerships and lay the foundation for a Massachusetts Integrated Landscape and Land Use Research for Sustainability (MILLURS) Network to support integrated land use planning and management. The Network will be comprised of diverse policymakers, civil society stakeholders, and researchers whose work at multiple scales intersects with land use planning in urban and rural communities. The planning grant aims to 1) characterize the connections among governmental and civil society actors whose efforts impact land use choices; 2) identify the structures and knowledge systems that have common goals or are barriers to integration; 3) co-develop models and identify measures for integrated land use governance goals; and 4) propose a structure for future work and identify potential pilot programs, research questions, and educational activities to accomplish in future efforts. This work will advance the science of sustainable urban-rural regional systems through the lens of land use by drawing together lessons emerging from the MILLURS Network and insights from three streams of scholarship and practice: multi-level governance; integrated knowledge systems and tools for sustainability and resilience; and analytic-deliberative processes to support co-learning and governance among diverse stakeholders. This project will advance collaborative governance by initiating collaboration among sectors where communication and coordination for governance and climate resilience is weak.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Massachusetts has ambitious goals for sustainability and climate resilience, including renewable energy and decarbonization, food security, housing security, economic security and vitality, equity and racial justice, functional and resilient ecosystems, and public health and community well-being. All have implications for land use, access, and management in urban, suburban, and rural areas. Land is required for energy generation and transmission infrastructure. Open space plays a critical role in resilient ecosystems, public health, livable communities, and climate resilient infrastructure. Land is necessary for farming in both rural and urban communities. Land is needed to secure housing for all. Efforts to achieve multiple goals create conflicts over land use and access.  

The goal of this convergence research project was to: 1) Characterize the institutional and policy networks and activities involved in land use, access, and management in Massachusetts; 2) Identify how land use and land access affect capabilities for achieving climate resilience and sustainability goals at local to regional scales and opportunities and challenges to regional, integrated planning in Massachusetts; 3) Identify future research, outreach, education activities to pursue.

We convened a Stakeholder Working Group, organized a workshop on the role of regional collaboratives in integrated, adaptive, equitable regional land-use planning, conducted a state-wide survey of civil society organizations, conducted interviews with stakeholders, convened a planning group for a regional dialogue about land-use in the Connecticut River Valley, and completed a policy analysis.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts has weak systems for regional and integrated land use planning and governance. Home rule locates much of the power for land use decisions within municipalities. While some powers are constrained, such as where it is not permissible to site utility scale solar systems, the state provides little guidance about how to plan at regional scales across multiple sectors.  Planning is often siloed, which can cause disconnections and mis-alignments in policy goals.  Regional Planning Agencies and watershed-based collaboratives fill some of the gaps between the local and state levels. 

The survey was a primary instrument to identify civil society groups in Massachusetts whose work has implications for land use, land access, and land management.  We received 304 usable responses from groups representing all counties of Massachusetts whose work touches on land use planning and management, for a response rate of 26%. The results suggest both challenges and opportunities for integrated planning.  On one hand, 71% of the respondents reported a concern that plans or decisions may result in conflicts among competing land use goals for energy generation systems, forest and open space protection, and/or housing development. Pressures on land use and land access in Massachusetts are creating tensions among important goals for climate resilience, sustainability, and livable communities.  They are exacerbated by the legacies of racism and economic marginalization, and inequities across rural to urban and west to east continuums. 

On the other hand, fifty percent of the respondents reported significant effort working across multiple policy sectors, including climate adaptation, climate mitigation, agriculture, open space protection, energy generation, forest management, housing and other development, public health, recreation, urban sustainability, water quality, and equity, diversity and racism. Participants in the Stakeholder Working Group and workshops emphasized that there is a need to go beyond a focus on the physical aspects of land to include the social, cultural, and spiritual values that make land, land-use, and land access important to people.  As one person said, “land is foundational to everything that we talk about” – for food, housing, energy, waste, carbon sequestration, transportation, water, open space, habitat, and quality of life.  

Our work contributes to the conceptual and practical understanding of multi-sector governance, or “nexus governance,” in multi-state, state, and sub-state (counties, municipalities) regional contexts, including watersheds.  The project revealed the complexity of how stakeholders’ efforts to define what “just and equitable integrated planning” looks like at different scales, from local, to watershed, to state, to multi-state scales. The work further contributes to understandings of how governance systems and lack of data create obstacles to regional and integrated land use planning; how those can undermine efforts to achieve aggressive climate resilience and sustainability goals, and how civil society and governmental actors grapple with the trade-offs inherent to sustainability transitions. The planning grant was an opportunity to build relationships that inform the creation of a network and the submission of follow-up proposals.  Stakeholders themselves established new relationships; the planning grant provided a unique and timely opportunity to create venues for sharing knowledge and developing strategies and motivation to seek ways to maintain them. With stakeholders, we identified ideas for future work, including in the areas of capacity building, research, networking, training, and strategizing.
